00009 /*
00010  * This file is the general header file for all parts of the MicroEMACS
00011  * display editor.  It contains definitions used by everyone, and it contains
00012  * the stuff you have to edit to create a version of the editor for a
00013  * specific operating system and terminal.
00014  */
00015 
00016 #ifndef _EDITOR_HEADER_
00017 #define _EDITOR_HEADER_
00018

00034 #if     VAX_VMS
00035 #define ANSI    1                       /* Normally used for VAX VMS    */
00036 #define VT52    0                       /* VT52 terminal (Zenith).      */
00037 #define TERMCAP 0                       /* Use TERMCAP                  */
00038 #define IBM_PC  0                       /* Standard IBM PC BIOS         */
00039 #endif

00043 #define VT52    0                       /* VT52 terminal (Zenith).      */

00063 #define CVMVAS  1                       /* C-V, M-V arg. in screens.    */
00064 
00065 #define VERSION_NUM "3.0"               /* Emacs editor Version number  */
00066 
00067 #define NFILEN  256                     /* # of bytes, file name        */
00068 #define NBUFN   16                      /* # of bytes, buffer name      */
00069 #define NLINE   256                     /* # of bytes, line             */
00070 #define NKBDM   256                     /* # of strokes, keyboard macro */
00071 #define NPAT    80                      /* # of bytes, pattern          */
00072 #define HUGE    1000                    /* Huge number                  */
00073 
00074 #define AGRAVE  0x60                    /* M- prefix,   Grave (LK201)   */
00075 #define METACH  0x1B                    /* M- prefix,   Control-[, ESC  */
00076 #define CTMECH  0x1C                    /* C-M- prefix, Control-\       */
00077 #define EXITCH  0x1D                    /* Exit level,  Control-]       */
00078 #define COTLCH  0x1E                    /* C- prefix,   Control-^       */
00079 #define HELPCH  0x1F                    /* Help key,    Control-_       */
00080 #define DEL_KEY 0x7F                    /* Del key, most keyboards      */
00081 
00082 #define COTL    0x0100                  /* Control flag, or'ed in       */
00083 #define META    0x0200                  /* Meta flag, or'ed in          */
00084 #define CTLX    0x0400                  /* ^X flag, or'ed in            */
00085 
00086 #define ABORT   2                       /* Death, ^G, abort, etc.       */
00087 
00088 #define FIOSUC  0                       /* File I/O, success.           */
00089 #define FIOFNF  1                       /* File I/O, file not found.    */
00090 #define FIOEOF  2                       /* File I/O, end of file.       */
00091 #define FIOERR  3                       /* File I/O, error.             */
00092 
00093 #define CFCPCN  0x0001                  /* Last command was C-P, C-N    */
00094 #define CFKILL  0x0002                  /* Last command was a kill      */
00095 
00096 /*
00097  * There is a window structure allocated for every active display window. The
00098  * windows are kept in a big list, in top to bottom screen order, with the
00099  * listhead at "wheadp". Each window contains its own values of dot and mark.
00100  * The flag field contains some bits that are set by commands to guide
00101  * redisplay; although this is a bit of a compromise in terms of decoupling,
00102  * the full blown redisplay is just too expensive to run for every input
00103  * character.
00104  */
00105 typedef struct  WINDOW {
00106         struct  WINDOW *w_wndp;         /* Next window                  */
00107         struct  BUFFER *w_bufp;         /* Buffer displayed in window   */
00108         struct  LINE *w_linep;          /* Top line in the window       */
00109         struct  LINE *w_dotp;           /* Line containing "."          */
00110         short   w_doto;                 /* Byte offset for "."          */
00111         struct  LINE *w_markp;          /* Line containing "mark"       */
00112         short   w_marko;                /* Byte offset for "mark"       */
00113         char    w_toprow;               /* Origin 0 top row of window   */
00114         char    w_ntrows;               /* # of rows of text in window  */
00115         char    w_force;                /* If NZ, forcing row.          */
00116         char    w_flag;                 /* Flags.                       */
00117 }       WINDOW;
00118 
00119 #define WFFORCE 0x01                    /* Window needs forced reframe  */
00120 #define WFMOVE  0x02                    /* Movement from line to line   */
00121 #define WFEDIT  0x04                    /* Editing within a line        */
00122 #define WFHARD  0x08                    /* Better to a full display     */
00123 #define WFMODE  0x10                    /* Update mode line.            */
00124 
00125 /*
00126  * Text is kept in buffers. A buffer header, described below, exists for every
00127  * buffer in the system. The buffers are kept in a big list, so that commands
00128  * that search for a buffer by name can find the buffer header. There is a
00129  * safe store for the dot and mark in the header, but this is only valid if
00130  * the buffer is not being displayed (that is, if "b_nwnd" is 0). The text for
00131  * the buffer is kept in a circularly linked list of lines, with a pointer to
00132  * the header line in "b_linep".
00133  */
00134 typedef struct  BUFFER {
00135         struct  BUFFER *b_bufp;         /* Link to next BUFFER          */
00136         struct  LINE *b_dotp;           /* Link to "." LINE structure   */
00137         short   b_doto;                 /* Offset of "." in above LINE  */
00138         struct  LINE *b_markp;          /* The same as the above two,   */
00139         short   b_marko;                /* but for the "mark"           */
00140         struct  LINE *b_linep;          /* Link to the header LINE      */
00141         char    b_nwnd;                 /* Count of windows on buffer   */
00142         char    b_flag;                 /* Flags                        */
00143         char    b_fname[NFILEN];        /* File name                    */
00144         char    b_bname[NBUFN];         /* Buffer name                  */
00145 }       BUFFER;
00146 
00147 #define BFTEMP  0x01                    /* Internal temporary buffer    */
00148 #define BFCHG   0x02                    /* Changed since last write     */
00149 
00150 /*
00151  * The starting position of a region, and the size of the region in
00152  * characters, is kept in a region structure.  Used by the region commands.
00153  */
00154 typedef struct  {
00155         struct  LINE *r_linep;          /* Origin LINE address.         */
00156         short   r_offset;               /* Origin LINE offset.          */
00157         long    r_size;                 /* Length in characters.        */
00158 }       REGION;
00159 
00160 /*
00161  * All text is kept in circularly linked lists of "LINE" structures. These
00162  * begin at the header line (which is the blank line beyond the end of the
00163  * buffer). This line is pointed to by the "BUFFER". Each line contains a the
00164  * number of bytes in the line (the "used" size), the size of the text array,
00165  * and the text. The end of line is not stored as a byte; it's implied. Future
00166  * additions will include update hints, and a list of marks into the line.
00167  */
00168 typedef struct  LINE {
00169         struct  LINE *l_fp;             /* Link to the next line        */
00170         struct  LINE *l_bp;             /* Link to the previous line    */
00171         short   l_size;                 /* Allocated size               */
00172         short   l_used;                 /* Used size                    */
00173         char    l_text[1];              /* A bunch of characters.       */
00174 }       LINE;
00175 
00176 #define lforw(lp)       ((lp)->l_fp)
00177 #define lback(lp)       ((lp)->l_bp)
00178 #define lgetc(lp, n)    ((lp)->l_text[(int) (n)]&0xFF)
00179 #define lputc(lp, n, c) ((lp)->l_text[(int) (n)]= (char) (c))
00180 #define llength(lp)     ((lp)->l_used)
00181 
00182 /*
00183  * The editor communicates with the display using a high level interface. A
00184  * "TERM" structure holds useful variables, and indirect pointers to routines
00185  * that do useful operations. The low level get and put routines are here too.
00186  * This lets a terminal, in addition to having non standard commands, have
00187  * funny get and put character code too. The calls might get changed to
00188  * "termp->t_field" style in the future, to make it possible to run more than
00189  * one terminal type.
00190  */
00191 
00192 
00193 typedef struct  {
00194         short   t_nrow;                 /* Number of rows.              */
00195         short   t_ncol;                 /* Number of columns.           */
00196         void    (*t_open)(void);        /* Open terminal at the start.  */
00197         void    (*t_close)(void);       /* Close terminal at end.       */
00198         int     (*t_getchar)(void);     /* Get character from keyboard. */
00199         void    (*t_putchar)(int);      /* Put character to display.    */
00200         void    (*t_flush)(void);       /* Flush output buffers.        */
00201         void    (*t_move)(int,int);     /* Move the cursor, origin 0.   */
00202         void    (*t_eeol)(void);        /* Erase to end of line.        */
00203         void    (*t_eeop)(void);        /* Erase to end of page.        */
00204         void    (*t_beep)(void);        /* Beep.                        */
00205 }       TERM;

00212  *  keys if desired.
